header.title: Highlights of Tarot with Coloring Instructions

central_thesis: The Tarot, particularly the 22 Major Trumps as presented by the Builders of the Adytum (B.O.T.A.), is a practical "textbook of occult teachings" and a "symbolic map of Consciousness" designed for inner growth and spiritual enlightenment. Its consistent meditative study and precise coloring, in accordance with specific instructions, facilitates the attunement of the subconscious mind to universal Cosmic Principles, leading to expanded states of consciousness and self-realization. The system emphasizes inner development over external phenomena and integrates Tarot with Qabalah to provide a complete understanding of Ageless Wisdom.

structure_content.summary: Explains the booklet's origin as a reference aid for B.O.T.A. students coloring Major Tarot Keys. It notes the expansion to include Minor Tarot Key coloring instructions due to growing public interest, but stresses that true "transmutational impact" comes from following the B.O.T.A. curriculum's coloring instructions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Publisher's Note to the Sixth Edition
structure_content.summary: Introduces Dr. Paul Foster Case as a world authority on Tarot and Qabalah, and the founder of B.O.T.A. It asserts his attainment of advanced Adeptship enabled him to attune to high spiritual levels, translating hitherto secret Ageless Wisdom teachings into accessible forms for modern spiritual and psychological integration.

Defines the Tarot as a 'textbook of occult teachings' for serious aspirants seeking spiritual enlightenment, emphasizing inner growth over external methods. It outlines the Tarot's two main functions: preserving and transmitting Esoteric Teaching, and evoking specific mystical and intellectual responses from the student's Inner Consciousness. It distinguishes Tarot from mere fortune-telling or a 'plaything'.

Discusses the Tarot's history, placing its appearance around 1200 AD based on occult tradition, while acknowledging earliest preserved designs from 1390. It refutes the popular Egyptian origin myth, crediting Mr. A. E. Waite for critiquing it and suggesting earlier occultists like Eliphas Levi perpetuated the myth to conceal true history. It states the Tarot was integrated into Ageless Wisdom teachings by Adepts in Fez to overcome language barriers, embodying spiritual principles and occult powers pictorially, and utilizing the Qabalah's numerological framework.

Presents endorsements of the Tarot's profound significance from notable figures. Judge Thomas Troward places Tarot alongside the Bible and Great Pyramid as records of supreme mysteries. P.D. Ouspensky views Tarot as a primary method for developing the 'sense of symbols' and understanding esoteric language. Eliphas Levi extols Tarot as a 'philosophical machine' and an 'oracle' for universal science, and Madame H.P. Blavatsky's known interest in Tarot is cited to suggest her deep knowledge of its symbology.

Instructs that the uncolored Tarot Tableau, provided as part of B.O.T.A. membership, is crucial for occult training. It strongly recommends against coloring the Keys until directed by the bi-weekly lessons. The act of looking at and studying the Keys is explained as a process of transferring their designs to brain cells, attuning the consciousness to the symbolized states, which is fundamental to advanced Tarot practice.

Provides a brief, non-exhaustive explanation of Tarot Keys, clarifying that the symbolism is Universal and relates to unchanging Cosmic Principles. It explains the use of astrological terms as symbolic rather than literal predictive influences. The Minor Trumps (56 cards) are introduced as symbolizing the four Qabalistic Worlds and alchemical elements, but are designated for 'very advanced students' only after mastering the Major Trumps.

Offers condensed meanings for each of the 22 Major Arcana Keys, linking them to Hebrew letters, astrological attributions, and core esoteric concepts. For instance, Key 0 (The Fool) represents the limitless Life-Power (Aleph), Key 1 (The Magician) symbolizes concentration, Key 8 (Strength) relates to the Kundalini force, Key 11 (Justice) signifies equilibrium and Karma, and Key 21 (The World) represents Cosmic Consciousness and the uses of limitation.

Presents comprehensive tables detailing the occult attributions for each Major Arcana Key. These include the assigned color, musical note, Hebrew letter and its meaning, letter number, astrological attribution, alchemical attribution, specific intelligences, and other esoteric correlations. This section serves as a practical reference for students to deepen their understanding of each Key's multi-faceted symbolic links.

structure_content.chapter_title: Why You Should Color Your Tarot Keys
structure_content.summary: Emphasizes that coloring the Tarot Keys correctly makes them significantly more powerful. This process links the cards to the practitioner's personality, impressing their archetypal patterns onto the brain cells, which is a 'practical secret of all occultism' and essential for advanced Tarot practice and consciousness expansion.

Provides general guidelines for the coloring process, advising students to visualize the completed card before applying color. It recommends using true and vivid coloring mediums and testing colors on white paper. It also cautions against coloring more than one Key per day and emphasizes reading specific instructions carefully for each card to avoid errors and ensure correct symbolic application.

Details specific color assignments for individual components of each of the 22 Major Arcana Keys (e.g., background, garments, symbols, figures). These precise instructions are integral to the B.O.T.A. method of imprinting the symbolic meanings onto the subconscious mind through active engagement with the visual forms.

structure_content.chapter_title: Coloring Instructions For The Minor Tarot Keys
structure_content.summary: Provides specific color assignments for the Ace, King, Queen, Knight, and Page of each of the four Minor Suits (Wands, Cups, Swords, and Pentacles). These instructions are intended for advanced students, to be approached only after mastering the Major Trumps, aligning with the hierarchical learning structure of B.O.T.A.'s esoteric curriculum.

key_concepts.definition: A practical 'textbook of occult teachings' and a 'symbolic map of Consciousness' for inner growth and spiritual enlightenment, distinct from mere fortune-telling. Its study and coloring activate specific mystical, intellectual, and emotional responses.

The overarching body of esoteric knowledge and timeless methods of Initiation in the Western Occult Tradition that the Tarot and Qabalah preserve and transmit, leading to spiritual and psychological integration.

The 'Mystery system of numbers and letters afforded by the QABALAH, or Secret Wisdom of Israel,' which forms the underlying framework for understanding and operating the Tarot system, connecting it to a comprehensive esoteric tradition.
The foundational set of Tarot cards representing 'sacred symbols' and abstract philosophy. Their mastery is a prerequisite for reliable spiritual development and for approaching the Minor Trumps.

The numerical and court cards, symbolizing the four Qabalistic Worlds (Archetypal, Creative, Formative, Material) and alchemical elements. Intended for 'very advanced students' after complete mastery of the Major Trumps due to their 'extremely difficult and abstract philosophy'.

The fundamental, universal radiant mental energy, vital principle, or cosmic power underlying all manifestation and evolution, referred to by various terms like Aleph, Pneuma, Prana, Ruach, Spiritus, Fohat, and Kundalini. It is symbolized by the Sun in Key 0 and Key 19.
The highest stage of spiritual unfoldment, attained through consistent Tarot practice, representing a profound understanding and unity with the Universal Life, as symbolized by Key 21 (The World).

An 'absolutely indispensable' practice for all aspirants, defined as 'limiting of the field of activity,' essential for developing inner growth and performing the 'Great Work' (spiritual transformation). Symbolized by Key 1 (The Magician).

A 'practical secret of all occultism' and 'necessary foundation for all advanced TAROT practice.' It involves precisely applying colors to the uncolored Keys to link them to the individual's personality, impress their archetypal patterns onto brain cells, and attune consciousness to the symbolized states. Requires prior study and visualization.

A 'great cosmic force' within the human organism, called FOHAT by Blavatsky. It is powerful for both destruction and integration. Its awakening should be natural and internally guided, with 'subconsciousness' (the woman in Key 8, Strength) controlling it in its latent state. Deliberate attempts to activate it are deemed 'most dangerous'.

The primary meaning of Key 12, referring to a fundamental shift in thought and point of view from the unenlightened multitude to that of an adept who realizes existence is dependent on Cosmic Law. It also implies 'Suspended Mind' or Samadhi, an exalted mental state of Divine Consciousness.

The keynote of Key 6, symbolized by a sword (Hebrew letter Zain) as an instrument of cleavage and the 'Disposing Intelligence.' It represents the ability to discern between opposites, leading to a deeper understanding of the Life-Force's specialization into male and female prototypes.

practical_system.description: The practical system centers on the meditative study and precise coloring of the B.O.T.A. Tarot Keys, especially the 22 Major Trumps, as a means to impress their archetypal patterns onto the subconscious mind. This process is designed to induce 'Expanded States of Consciousness' and ultimately 'Cosmic Consciousness.' The method promotes an internal, alchemical transformation of the individual's consciousness, leading to spiritual growth and self-mastery. The system explicitly links Tarot to the Qabalah, astrological, and alchemical attributions to provide a multi-layered framework for understanding and operative practice.
tools: B.O.T.A. Tarot Keys/Tableau: Uncolored sets of the 22 Major Trumps (and later, 56 Minor Trumps), which are seen as 'special tools' and 'very valuable instrument'.
Coloring Mediums: Water colors, paints, crayons, or other art materials, selected for 'true and vivid' colors, used to apply the precise color instructions.
B.O.T.A. Lesson Material: The bi-weekly correspondence lessons that provide the 'esoteric instructions' for the coloring process and 'more extended and thorough teachings' for understanding.

Personal Consciousness: The practitioner's own 'brain cells' and 'Inner Consciousness' serve as the primary 'instrument' and 'workbench' that is actively modified and attuned through engagement with the Tarot designs and their symbolism.
rituals: Daily Study and Meditative Viewing: Continuously 'look at the KEYS,' 'use them daily; study their details and pay attention to similarities and contrast.' Place each Key 'where you will always have it to refer to â€” in your own consciousness' to transfer designs to brain cells.
Pre-coloring Visualization: Before applying any color to a card, 'try to visualize exactly what it will look like when it is completed.' This enhances the suggestive power of the Keys.

Focused Coloring Practice: Color 'no more than one TAROT KEY in a given day,' and complete 'each card at one sitting if possible.' Crucially, 'read the symbolic interpretation of it very attentively and keep it in your mind as you proceed with the work' to firmly implant symbolic meaning in consciousness.

relevant_quotes.text: The TAROT is a textbook of occult teachings. It is intended for the use of serious aspirants who are in search of spiritual enlightenment, and who are willing to devote a reasonable amount of time and thought to the discovery of the deeper meaning of life.

The TAROT serves both classes by strengthening the emotional-intuitional nature of the one, and developing balanced intellectual qualities in the other. In this way the second function of TAROT, the evocation of creative states of con-sciousness, is of great importance.

TAROT is intensely practical. It is intended for use every day. Its principles are applicable to the problems which confront everyone in the course of everyday existence. Its function is to induce the power-ful Expanded States of Consciousness in the indi-vidual aspirant that will enable him to cope with life efficiently, to understand the spiritual meaning and significance of his experience and environment and its relation to himself as an Eternal Being.
As a skeleton for this additional aid to the spiritual evolution of humanity the Adepts chose the Western Mystery system of numbers and letters afforded by the QABALAH, or Secret Wisdom of Israel...

Coloring your own TAROT KEYS is a very important aspect of your occult training... When you color your own cards they take on the character of your personality. They are inseparably linked with you! The attention you must give impresses their patterns upon the cells of your brain-builds the details of the designs into your con-sciousness. And making the TAROT KEYS a part of yourself is one of the most practical secrets of all occultism.

The wisdom contained in the sacred symbols of the 22 Major Trumps must be mastered before the student may approach the ex-tremely difficult and abstract philosophy veiled in the numeral symbols of the so-called Minor Trumps.
However, you can ac-complish nothing at all if you fail to use the TAROT. It is a truly magical instrument, and it will work won-ders for you, but you must never forget that you are the Magician.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book provides a concise yet dense introduction to the B.O.T.A. Tarot system, emphasizing its practical application for spiritual development rather than mere divination. It highlights the integration of Qabalah, astrology, and alchemical principles, situating Tarot within a coherent esoteric framework. The clear instructions for coloring are directly operative, making it a valuable resource for students actively engaging with the B.O.T.A. curriculum or seeking a structured approach to esoteric Tarot study. It clarifies the B.O.T.A. perspective, differentiating it from popular misconceptions about Tarot's historical origins and use, and provides a foundational understanding of its symbology as a tool for consciousness expansion.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of students of Builders of the Adytum (B.O.T.A.) who are working through their curriculum and coloring their Tarot Keys. It also serves serious aspirants in Western Esotericism, occultism, and Qabalah who are seeking a structured, non-superficial, and practical approach to Tarot as a tool for self-transformation and consciousness expansion. It appeals to those interested in the 'Ageless Wisdom' tradition and the synthesis of various occult sciences, and explicitly states it is not for casual readers seeking quick interpretations or purely divinatory uses.
